text: Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know.

text: Patient: Until the third of January or something. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now.

text: Patient: We’re hoping you got the samples switched or something like that. Doctor: You know I was actually gonna check that and I haven’t done that. Family Member: I would like to check it just for peace of mind only, but there’s nothing that would lead us to think it was all this and to be fifty to sixty percent involved with the prostate kind of blew our minds a little bit. Doctor: Me too. Yeah. Patient: It doesn’t add up. Family Member: It really doesn’t. It just doesn’t, so. Doctor: So, I forgot, I was actually gonna check that and I will, I forgot but I will do that. text: Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself?

text: Family Member 1: And she does yoga. Doctor: I’m very relaxed in here. Oh my gosh. (laughing) Family Member 1: She teaches yoga too Doctor. Doctor: Are you okay? Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
